c74object.name: cage.sdif.fzero.toroll
c74object.digest: Import a fundamental frequency SDIF analysis into a bach.roll
c74object.description: Imports and displays a fundamental frequency SDIF analysis into a bach.roll object. Each stream is mapped to a different voice.

inlet.description: The SDIF analysis containing fundamental frequency information, as the one output by bach.readsdif.

Frame amplitudes output from this lambda outlet can be mapped into velocities to be re-injected into this lambda inlet. A lambda inlet is an inlet receiving the answer from a test or modification performed on elements sent out the lambda outlets.
In this case, the answer is expected to be a modification of the elements which had been sent out: the element output via the lambda outlet can be customly modified and then plugged in into this lambda inlet: such modification will be accounted for by the algorithm.
The lambda inlet also accepts the result in llll form, so you can sometimes avoid the explicit @out t.
It is important to know that the evaluation chain inside the lambda loop must be direct: you can't use objects such as delay, pipe, defer; nor store the value anywhere waiting for some other event to trigger it. Also see #lambda in the bach Help Center.

outlet.description:
Frame amplitudes are output from this lambda outlet. Such amplitudes might be mapped into velocities to be re-injected into the lambda inlet. A lambda outlet is an outlet outputting an element on which some test or modification must be performed. The result of the test or modification is then expected in a lambda inlet.
In this case, the elements output from the lambda outlet may be customly modified, so that such modification will be taken into account by the algorithm. To modify each element, just use patching and then plug into the lambda inlet the modified version of the element.
It is important to know that the evaluation chain inside the lambda loop must be direct: you can't use objects such as delay, pipe, defer; nor store the value anywhere waiting for some other event to trigger it. Also see #lambda in the bach Help Center.

method.name: bang
method.description: Output the information imported from the most recently input analysis llll.

method.name: llll
method.description:
An llll in first inlet is expected to contain the llll form of a fundamental frequency SDIF analysis (as the one output by bach.readsdif). The output bach.roll's gathered syntax is is sent through the outlet (each SDIF stream corresponding to a voice).
An llll in second inlet is converted into an int.

attribute.name: align
allowglissandi
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to convert the fundamental frequency melodic line into notes whose duration lines have glissandi (i.e. pitch breakpoints). The granularity of the glissando is also determined by the first element of the reducethresh attribute. By default this attribute is off.

attribute.name: ampslot
attribute.description: Sets the number of the (function) slot which will contain the amplitude envelope of each note, or leave 0 to ignore this envelope (default).

attribute.name: confidenceslot
attribute.description: Sets the number of the (function) slot which will contain the phase envelope of each note, or leave 0 to ignore this envelope (default).

attribute.name: connection
attribute.description: Sets a connection threshold, in cents. Frames whose pitches are more distant than this threshold will begin a new note; otherwise the existing note will continue. Default is 50mc.

attribute.name: freqrange
attribute.description: Narrow the output to a custom frequency range: a minimum frequency and a maximum frequency, both in Hertz. Frames whose frequencies are outside this range will cause the end of a possible ongoing note. Default frequency range is 20 Hz to 20000 Hz.

attribute.name: minamp
attribute.description: Sets a minimum amplitude threshold. Frames whose amplitude is under this threshold will cause the end of a possible ongoing note. Default is 0.001.

attribute.name: minconfidence
attribute.description: Sets a minimum confidence threshold. Frames whose confidence is under this threshold will cause the end of a possible ongoing note. Default is 0.001.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: reducethresh
attribute.description: Envelopes and duration lines by default are not output with one breakpoint for each peak; on the contrary, such envelopes are smoothed (as bach.reducefunction does, with relative attribute set to 0). The smoothing thresholds (see the the thresh attribute of bach.reducefunction) are entered via this attribute, in the following sequence: the smoothing threshold for the duration line breakpoints (in midicents, default: 10), the smoothing threshold for the amplitude envelopes (default: 0.01), the smoothing threshold for the confidence envelopes (default: 0.01) and the smoothing threshold for the score envelopes (default: 0.01).

attribute.name: scoreslot
attribute.description: Sets the number of the (function) slot which will contain the score envelope of each note, or leave 0 to ignore this envelope (default).

entry.name: Inlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: SDIF analysis as llll. The SDIF analysis containing fundamental frequency information, as the one output by bach.readsdif.

entry.name: Inlet 2 (llll)
entry.description:
Lambda inlet. Frame amplitudes output from this lambda outlet can be mapped into velocities to be re-injected into this lambda inlet. A lambda inlet is an inlet receiving the answer from a test or modification performed on elements sent out the lambda outlets.
In this case, the answer is expected to be a modification of the elements which had been sent out: the element output via the lambda outlet can be customly modified and then plugged in into this lambda inlet: such modification will be accounted for by the algorithm.
The lambda inlet also accepts the result in llll form, so you can sometimes avoid the explicit @out t.
It is important to know that the evaluation chain inside the lambda loop must be direct: you can't use objects such as delay, pipe, defer; nor store the value anywhere waiting for some other event to trigger it. Also see #lambda in the bach Help Center.

entry.name: Outlet 2 (llll)
entry.description:
Lambda outlet. Frame amplitudes are output from this lambda outlet. Such amplitudes might be mapped into velocities to be re-injected into the lambda inlet. A lambda outlet is an outlet outputting an element on which some test or modification must be performed. The result of the test or modification is then expected in a lambda inlet.
In this case, the elements output from the lambda outlet may be customly modified, so that such modification will be taken into account by the algorithm. To modify each element, just use patching and then plug into the lambda inlet the modified version of the element.
It is important to know that the evaluation chain inside the lambda loop must be direct: you can't use objects such as delay, pipe, defer; nor store the value anywhere waiting for some other event to trigger it. Also see #lambda in the bach Help Center.
